Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 Conference on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal supports student travel to attend the Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES) conference, to be held in Atlanta in August 2019. CHES is one of the leading international conferences on research on both design and analysis of cryptographic hardware and software implementations. The conference is a premier venue for new results from the research community as well as from the industry. Participation in conferences such as CHES is an extremely important part of graduate students' research and career development, providing the opportunity for them to present their own work, attend panel and keynote speech sessions, interact with peers and senior researchers, and exposure to leading edge work in all aspects of cryptographic hardware and security in embedded systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provides opportunities for selected students to attend the 2019 Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems conference (CHES 2019), held in Atlanta, Georgia in September 2019. The Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES) conference is the premier venue for research on both design and analysis of cryptographic hardware and software implementations. As an area conference of the International Association for CryptologicResearch (IACR), CHES bridges the cryptographic research and engineering communities, and it attracts participants from academia, industry, government and beyond. The IACR is a non-profit organization devoted to supporting the promotion of the science of cryptology. 

CHES 2019 took place in Atlanta, Georgia. The costs of participating at the conference includes a registration fee, travel costs and lodging. The above mentioned costs are prohibitive for many talented students and a grant is necessary. This is especially true when students do not have a publication at CHES, which means that the incurred travel cost is harder to justify through an existing research grant. 

Through a selection process, nineteen students have been selected from ten US universities to attend CHES 2019. They met with other researchers in the research field and networked with potential employers. The students were also able to learn about the most recent developments in the area.
The student selection process used a formal application including a review by an external selection committee. The selection committee emphasized support for female students and underrepresented groups.
